entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French pretendre, from Latin praetendere to allege as an excuse, literally, to stretch out, from prae- pre- + tendere to stretch thin

def.dt: :to give a false appearance of being, possessing, or performing does not pretend to be a psychiatrist
:to claim, represent, or assert falsely pretending an emotion he could not really feel
:to feign an action, part, or role especially in play
:to put in a claim cannot pretend to any particular expertise Clive Barnes
:imaginary make-believe had a pretend pal with whom he talked
:being a nonfunctional imitation a pretend train for the children to play in
